body.div:
I lay
on my
straw
but I could not
sleep –
I thought of the
occurences
of
the day.– What
cheifly
struck me was
the gentle manners of these
people,
and
I longed to join
them
but dared
not.—
I remembered too well the treatment I
had suffered the night before
fro
n
m
the barbarous
villagers
and
resolved
whatever
I should
^
course of conduct I might
afterwards think it
hereafter
consider
right to do
it
proper
to
pursue
that for the present I would
remain quietly in my
hovel watching
and endeavouring to discover the
motive
of
their
motions actions.—
The
y
^
cottagers arose the next morning before
the
sun;–
The young woman arranged the
cottage
&
per prepared the food; & the
youth
mounted on a large strange animal
road rode away. This
day was passed in
the same routine
and
as
the preceeding one.
The
young young man was constantly
employed out of
doors
and the girl in
various laborious occupations within.
.
— The old
man
whom I soon perceived to be
blind
employed his leisure hours
in playing
on his
instrument
or in
pesively
contemplation –
Nothing could exceed
the love & respect
that
the younger
cottagers
bore shewed
towards
this
venerable
old man –
They performed towards
^
him
every
little office of
love affection & duty with gentleness;
and he rewarded them by his
benevo
lent
smiles.
B
They
were not
however entirely
happy–The youth
young
er man
d & his
companion,
often
retired into a corner
of their common room and wept.
I saw
no cause for
this unhappiness
but
I was deeply affected by
it –
If such
lovely creatures were
miserable
it was
less strange that
alone' d I, an imperfect
and solitary
being
should be
wretched—
yet why were these gentle beings
un
happy –
they
poss
^
ess ed
a delightful house
for
such
^
it
was
it to
in
my
eyes)
and every
luxury.
they had a fire to warm
them when
chill
and delicious viands
when
hungry–
they were dressed
in clothes that kept t in
excel
lent clothes and
still
more
they
enjoy
ed
one
anothers
company
& speech — and saw
interchanged
each day looks of affection &
kindness–
What did their tears
mean?
Did they
really express pain? I was at first
unable to solve these
questions
but
perpetual
attention
and
time
explained to me many
of the appear
ances
which at first
seemed
igmmatic enigmatic . o you pretty Pecksie!
Chap. 3
It was some time
^
A
considerable period elapsed before I discovered one
of the causes of the uneasiness of this amiable
family –
It Itw
^
It was
poverty–
and they suffered
that evil in a very distressing
degree– Dur
ring the winter They often had hardly any
their nourishment consisted entirely of
bread
and – the vegetables of their
garden
and the
milk of one
cow
which
gave very little
during the
hard monthes winter
when
the its masters could
spare
scarcely
very little
money towards the procur i e ng
^
any of
food
for
it.
This state of poverty They
often
I
believe d
suffered the pangs of hunger very
poi
gnantly
especially the two
young
er er part
for
^
several times
they
often placed food before the old
man
when
they
^
were
themselves in want of it
they
had
none for
their themselves –This
trait of kindness moved me sensibly.
I had been
accustomed
during the
night
to steal a part of their store for my
own consumption; but when I found
that in doing this I inflicted pain on the
cottagers, I abstained, and satisfied
my
self
with
berries nuts
and
roots
which
I
found in
gathered from
a neighbouring wood.
I found
^
discovered
also
another means
by
which I was
able
to assist their labours. I found that the
youth spent a great part of each
day in
felling collecting wood for the
family
fire–and
during the
night
I often
took his
tools
the
com use of which I
quickly
discovered
and brought home
for them firing sufficient
^
for the consumption
f o r f seve
ral days–
[ I remember
the first time that I
did this, the young
woman who
opened
the door in the
morning
was
appeared greatly
sur
prised astonished to see
a great pile of wood on
the
outside –
she
said
some words in a
loud voice, &
presently the youth joined
her
who also
appeared astonished. and
I
observed th
with
pleasure
that he
did not go to the
wood
^
forest
that
day
but
spent it in repairing the
cottage
&
in
cultivating the
garden.—
Soon after
^
By degrees also I made another discovery
which was that
to me of still
greater
moment
^
to me I
found
^
that
these people ha d posessed a
means method of communicating their ideas experience & to
feelings one another
by articulate
sounds which
they uttered som — w
I
often percieved
that
the words they spoke
^
sometimes
produced
plea
sure
pain, smiles or
sadness
in the
minds & countenances of the
hear ee ers –
This was
indeed a Godlike
science
and I ardently
wished
desired
to become acquainted with
it–But
I was baffled in every attempt
they
I
made for this
purpose
Their pronunciation was
quick
& the
words they
uttered seemed had
not having
any apparent
co connexion
with
the visible
objects
I was unable to discover any clue
by which I could
unrable
the mystery
of their
sounds.
application reference.
. By great
application how
ever
and after having remained
^
during the space of
several
revolutions of the moon in my
hovel
I discovered the names that were given
to some of the most familiar objects
of
discourse,
I learned
^
& applied
the
words
fire, mil k
bread
&
wood
I learned also the names
of the cottagers
themsel f v es– but as
the
y
^
youth & his companion
had
h each of them several
but
the old man had only
one
which
was
Father –
the girl was
call ed Sist
Sister
or
Agatha
and the youth
Felix.
^
or brother
or
son
I
c cannot describe the delight
I felt when I
discovered
^
learned
the ideas
opp
appropriated to each of these
sounds
and was able to pronounce them.
But
I
learned
^
distinguished
several other
sounds words
without being able
^
as yet
to understand
th or
apply
them – Among these
Such as
good
dearest – unhappy .
I
spent the winter in this
manner–
the gentle manners and beauty of the
cottagers greatly endeared them to
me–
When
they were
unhappy
I felt
depressed and
I
sympathized
in their joys. I saw few
human beings
besides them,
and if
any other happened to enter the
cottage
their harsh
and rud manners & rude
gait only enhanced to me
th my friends
the superior
advantages
of my friends.
The
Father old man, I could
percieve,
often endeavoured to encourage his
children
as
I sometimes
found that
he called
them.
^
to cast off their melancholy. He would talk in
a cheerful
accent
with an
aspect
expression of
godn goodness that
even gave
^
me delight. bestowed pleasure
even
on me;
Agatha listened with
respect–
her eyes
f sometimes filled with
tears
which
she endeavoured to wipe
d away
unpercieved
but I general
ly found that her
manners
and tone
were more cheerful after having
listen
end
to
the the exhortations of her
father
It was not thus with Felix. He was
always the saddest of the
groupe And
even
to my unpractised
senses
he
appeared to have suffered more
deeply than his friends. But if his
countenance was more
sorrowful
his voice was more cheerful than
that of his
sister es expecially
when he
addressed the old
man—
I
could mention innumerable
instances
which
although
slight
marked the
heart
dispositions
in
of
which
these amiable
cottagers shewed
their dispositions .
In the midst of poverty
and
want
Felix carried with pleasure
to his sister the
fist
little white flower
that peeped out from beneath the
snow
snowy
white ground
Early
I i n the
morning
early before
any of the
she had
risen
he
had cleared away the
snow that
obst
^
r ucted
her path to the
milkhouse – ;
drew water from the
well
and brought the wood from the
' outhouse
X
X
outhouse
where
to his
perpetual
astonishment
he found his
store always
replenished by
an invisible
hand.
In the
day
I
believe
he worked sometimes
for a neighbouring farmer,
for
because
he
often went
out
forth,
and did not return
untill
dinner, yet brought no wood
with
him:–
at other times he worked
in the
garden but
as there was
litt
e
le
to do in the frosty
season
he
often
read to the old man and Agatha.
This
reading had puzzled me extremely
at
first – but
by
degrees
I discovered
that he uttered many of the same
sounds when he
read
as when he
talked;
I
conjectured their therefore
that he
found on the paper signs for speech
which he
understood
and I ardently
longed
to understand
^
comprehend these b also; but how was
